note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: The Queene of Corinth,

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: _THe Generall is returned then?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: With much honour.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And peace concluded with the Prince of Argos?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: To the Queens wiſhes: the conditions ſign'd
So farre beyond her hopes, to the advantage
Of Corinth, and the good of all her Subjects;
That though Leonidas our brave Generall
Ever came home a faire and great example,
He never yet return'd, or with leſſe loſſe
Or more deſerved honour.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Have you not heard
The motives to this generall good?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: The maine one
Was admiration firſt in young Agenor,
(For by that name we know the Prince of Argos)
Of our Leonidas wiſedome, and his valour,
Which though an enemy, firſt in him bred wonder;
That liking, Love ſucceeded that, which was
Followed by a deſire to be a friend
Upon what termes ſoever to ſuch goodneſſe;
They had an enterview; and that their friendſhip
Might with our peace be ratified, 'twas concluded,
Agenor yeelding up all ſuch ſtronge places
As he held in our Territories, ſhould receive
(With a ſufficient Dower, paid by the Queene)
The faire Merione for his wife.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: But how
Approves the Queene of this? ſince we well know,
Nor was her Highneſſe ignoant, that her Sonne
The Prince Theanor made love to this Lady,
And in the nobleſt way.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Which ſhe allowed of,
And I have heard from ſome familiar with
Her neereſt ſecrets, ſhe ſo deeply priz'd her
Being from an Infant train'd up in her ſervice,
(Or to ſpeake better, rather her owne Creature)
She once did ſay, That if the Prince ſhould ſteale
A Marriage without her leave, or knowledge,
With this Merione, with a little ſuit
She ſhould grant both their pardons: where as now
To ſhew her ſelfe forſooth a Spartan Lady,
And that 'tis in her power, now it concernes
The common good, not alone to ſubdue
Her owne affections, but command her Sons;
She has not onely forc'd him with rough threats
To leave his Miſtris, but compell'd him when
Agenor made his entrance into Corinth
To wait upon his Rivall.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Can it be
The Prince ſhould ſit downe with this wrong?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I know not,
I am ſure I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Truſt me nor I,
A Mother is a name, but put in ballance
With a yong wench 'tis nothing; where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Neere Veſta's Temple, for there he diſmiſs'd me,
And full of troubled thoughts, calling for Crates:
He went with him, but whither or to what purpoſe
I am a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: They are come backe Neanthes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I like the place well.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Well Sir? it is built
As if the Architect had been a Prophet,
And faſhion'd it alone for this nights action;
The vaults ſo hollow, and the walls ſo ſtrong,
As Dian there might ſuffer violence,
And with loud ſhrikes in vaine call Jove to helpe her;
Or ſhould he heare, his thunder could not finde
An entrance to it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I give up my ſelfe
Wholly to thy direction, worthieſt Crates;
And yet the deſperate cure that we muſt practice
Is in it ſelfe ſo foule, and full of danger,
That I ſtand doubtfull whether 'twere more manly
To dye not ſeeking helpe, or that helpe being
So deadly, to purſue it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: To thoſe reaſons
I have already urg'd, I will adde theſe.
For but conſider Sir—

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: It is of weight
What ere it be, that with ſuch vehement action,
Of eye, hand, foot, nay all his bodies motion,
Crates incites the Prince to.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Then obſerve,
With what variety of paſſions he
Receives his reaſons; now he's pale, and ſhakes
For feare or anger; now his naturall red
Comes backe againe, and with a pleaſing ſmile
He ſeemes to entertaine it; 'tis reſolv'd on
Be it what 'twill: to his ends may it proſper
Though the State ſinke for't.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Now you are a Prince
Fit to rule others, and in ſhaking off
The Bonds in which your Mother fetters you
Diſcharge your debt to nature, ſhe's your guide,
Follow her boldly Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am confirm'd,
Fall what may fall,

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Yet ſtill diſguiſe your malice
In your humility.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Though in your heart there rage a thouſand tem|peſts,
All calmeneſſe in your lookes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhall remember.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: And at no hand, though theſe are us'd as agents
Acquaint them with your purpoſe till the inſtant
That we employ them; tis not fit they have
Time to conſider, when 'tis done, reward
Or feare will keep them ſilent: yet you may
Grace them as you paſſe by, 'twill make them ſurer,
And greedier to deſerve you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ile move onely
As you would have me: Good day gentlemen;
Nay, ſpare this ceremonious forme of duty
To him that brings love to you, equall love,
And is in nothing happier, then in knowing
It is return'd by you; we are as one.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: I am ore-joyd, I know not
How to reply: but—

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Hang all buts; my Lord,
For this your bounteous favour—

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Let me ſpeake,
If to feed Vultures hereafter the halter
Has done his part, or if there be a Hell
To take a ſwindge or two there, may deſerve this.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: We are ready.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Try us any way.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Put us to it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What jewels I have in you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Have theſe ſoules,
That for a good looke, and a few kinde words
Part with their eſſence?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Since you will compell me
To put that to the tryall, which I doubt not,
Crates may be ſuddenly will inſtruct you
How, and in what to ſhew your loves; obey him
As you would binde me to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Tis well grounded;
Leave me to reare the building.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: We will doe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Any thing youl put us to. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Siſter, I reape the harveſt of my labours
In your preferment, be you worthy of it,
And with an open boſome entertaine
A greater fortune then my love durſt hope for;
Be wiſe, and welcome it: play not the coy
And fooliſh wanton, with the offerd bounties
Of him that is a Prince. I was woo'd for you,
And won Merione: then if you dare
Beleeve the object that tooke me was worthy,
Or truſt my judgement, in me think you were
Courted, ſued to, and conquerd.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Noble brother,
I have, and ſtill eſteeme you as a Father,
And will as farre obey you; my heart ſpeakes it:
And yet without your anger give me leave
To ſay, That in the choice of that on which
All my lifes joyes or ſorrowes have dependance,
It had been fit ere you had made a full
And abſolute grant of me to any other,
I ſhould have us'd mine owne eyes, or at leaſt
Made you to underſtand, whether it were
Within my power to make a ſecond gift
Of my poore ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know what tis you point at,
The Prince Theanos love; let not that cheat you;
His vowes were but meere courtſhip; all his ſervice
But practiſe how to entrap a credulous Lady:
Or grant it ſerious, yet you muſt remember
He's not to love but where the Queene his Mother
Muſt give allowance, which to you is barr'd up:
And therefore ſtudy to forget that ever
You cheriſht ſuch a hope.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would I could.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But brave Agenor, who is come in perſon
To celebrate this Marriage, for your love
Forgives the forfeit of ten thouſand lives,
That muſt have falne under the ſword of war
Had not this peace been made; which generall good
Both Countries owe to his affection to you:
O happy Siſter, aske this noble Lady
Your boſome friend (ſince I faile in my credit)
What palme Agenors name above all Princes
That Greece is proud of carries, and with luſtre.

sp.speaker: Rel.
sp.l: Indeed fame gives him out of excellent;
And friend, I doubt not but when you ſhall ſee him
He'l ſo appeare to you. Art ſure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As I live Madam—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Vertue enable me to containe my joy.
'Tis my Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And he's in health?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Moſt certainly Madam,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ile ſee him inſtantly.
So prethee tell him. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I yeeld my ſelfe too weake
In argument to oppoſe you: you may leade me
Whither you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis anſwer'd like my Siſter;
And if in him you finde not ample cauſe
To pray for me, and daily on your knees,
Conclude I have no judgement.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: May it prove ſo:
Friend, ſhall we have your company?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Two houres hence
I will not faile you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: At your pleaſure Madam. Exit Leo. and Mer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Could I in one word ſpeake a thouſand welcomes
(And hearty ones) you have 'em: Fie, my hand,
We ſtand at no ſuch diſtance, by my life
The parting kiſſe you tooke before your travell
Is yet a virgin on my lips, preſerv'd
With as much care as I would doe my fame,
To entertaine your wiſh'd returne.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Beſt Lady,
That I doe honour you, and with as much reaſon
As ever man did vertue; that I love you,
Yet looke upon you with that reverence
As holy men behold the Sun, the Starrs,
The Temples, and their gods, they all can witneſſe;
And that you have deſerv'd this duty from me;
The life, and meanes of life, for which I owe you,
Commands me to profeſſe it, ſince my fortune
Affords no other payment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes, where benefits are ill conferr'd,
I had thought,
That for the trifling courteſies as I call them,
(Though you give them another name) you had
Made ample ſatisfaction in th' acceptance,
And therefore did preſume you had brought home
Some other Language.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: No one I have learn'd
Yeelds words ſufficient to expreſſe your goodneſſe;
Nor can I ever chuſe another theame
And not be thought unthankfull.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray you no more
As you reſpect me.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That charme is too powerfull
For me to diſobey it: 'Tis your pleaſure,
And not my boldneſſe Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes,
Beleeve I am not one of thoſe weak Ladies,
That (barren of all inward worth) are proud
Of what they cannot truly call their owne,
Their birth or fortune, which are things without them,
Nor in this will I imitate the world,
Whoſe greater part of men think when they give
They purchaſe bondmen, not make worthy friends:
By all that's good I ſweare, I never thought
My great eſtate was an addition to me,
Or that your wants took from you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: There are few
So truly underſtanding or themſelves
Or what they doe poſſeſſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes,
Where benefits
Are ill conferr'd as to unworthy men,
That turne them to bad uſes, the beſtower
For wanting judgement how, and on whom to place them,
Is partly guilty: but when we do favours
To ſuch as make them grounds on which they build
Their noble actions, there we improve our fortunes
To the moſt faire advantage. If I ſpeake
Too much, though I confeſſe I ſpeak well,
Prethee remember 'tis a womans weakneſſe,
And then thou wilt forgive it.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You ſpeake nothing
But what would well become the wiſeſt man:
And that by you deliver'd is ſo pleaſing
That I could heare you ever.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fly not from
Your word, for I arreſt it: and will now
Expreſſe my ſelfe a little more, and prove
That whereas you profeſſe your ſelfe my debtor,
That I am yours.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Your Ladiſhip then muſt uſe
Some Sophiſtry I ne're heard of.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By plaine reaſons,
For looke you, had you never ſunk beneath
Your wants, or if thoſe wants had found ſupply
From Crates, your unkinde and covetous brother,
Or any other man, I then had miſs'd
A ſubject upon which I worthily
Might exerciſe my bounty: whereas now
By having happy opportunity
To furniſh you before, and in your travells,
With all conveniencies that you thought uſefull,
That Gold which would have ruſted in my Coffers
Being thus imploy'd, has rendred me a partner
In all your glorious actions. And whereas
Had you not been, I ſhould have di'd a thing.
Scarce knowne, or ſoone forgotten: there's no Trophy
In which Euphanes for his worth is mentioned,
But there you have been carefull to remember,
That all the good you did came from Beliza.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That was but thankfulneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Twas ſuch an honour,
And ſuch a large returne for the poore traſh.
I ventur'd with you, that if I ſhould part
With all that I poſſeſſe, and my ſelfe too
In ſatisfaction for it, 'twere ſtill ſhort
Of your deſervings.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You o're-prize them Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The Queen her ſelfe hath given me gracious thanks
In your behalfe, for ſhe hath heard Euphanes
How gallantly you have maintain'd her honour
In all the Courts of Greece: and reſt aſſur'd,
(Though yet unknown) when I preſent you to her,
Which I will doe this evening, you ſhall finde
That ſhe intends good to you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Worthieſt Lady,
Since all you labour for is the advancement
Of him that will live ever your poore ſervant,
He muſt not contradict it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here's your Brother,
'Tis ſtrange to ſee him here.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You are welcome home Sir,
(Your pardon Madam) I had thought my houſe,
Conſidering who I am, might have been worthy
Of your firſt viſit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: 'Twas not open to me
When laſt I ſaw you; and to me 'tis wonder
That abſence which ſtill renders men forgotten
Should make my preſence wiſh'd for.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That's not it,
Your too kinde Brother underſtanding that
You ſtand in no need of him, is bold to offer
His entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He had never wanted,
Or yours, or your aſſiſtance, had he practiz'd
The way he might have tooke, to have commanded
What ever I call mine,

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I ſtudied many,
But could finde none.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You would not finde your ſelfe Sir,
Or in your ſelfe what was from you due to me:
The priviledge my birth beſtow'd upon me
Might challenge ſome regard.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You had all the Land Sir,
What elſe did you expect? and I am certaine
You kept ſuch ſtrong Guards to preſerve it yours
I could force nothing from you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Did you ever
Demand helpe from me?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: My wants have, and often,
With open mouthes, but you nor heard, nor ſaw them;
May be you look'd I ſhould petition to you
As you went to your Horſe; flatter your ſervants,
To play the Brokers for my furtherance,
Sooth your worſe humours, Act the Paraſite
On all occaſions, write my name with theirs
That are but one degree remov'd from ſlaves,
Be drunk when you would have me, then wench with you,
Or play the Pander; enter into Quarrels
Although unjuſtly grounded, and defend them
Becauſe they were yours; theſe are the tyrannies
Moſt younger Brothers groane beneath; yet beare them
From the inſulting Heire, ſelling their freedomes
At a leſſe rate then what the State allowes,
The ſallary of baſe and common Strumpets:
For my part, ere on ſuch low termes I feed
Upon a Brothers trencher, let me dye
The Beggers death, and ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely ſpoken,
Did what you doe ranke with it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why, what does he
You would not wiſh were yours?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ile tell you Lady,
Since you riſe up his Advocate, and boldly,
(For now I finde, and plainly, in whoſe favour
My love and ſervice to you was neglected)
For all your wealth, nay, adde to that your beauty,
And put your vertues in if you have any,
I would not yet be pointed at, as he is,
For the fine Courtier, the womans man,
That tells my Lady ſtories, diſſolves riddles,
Uſhers her to Coach, lyes at her feet
At ſollemne Maskes, applauding what ſhe laughs at;
Reads her aſleep a nights, and takes his oath
Upon her Pantoffles, that all excellence
In other Madams doe but zany hers:
Theſe you are perfect in, and yet theſe take not
Or from your birth or freedome.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Should another
Say this, my deeds, not lookes ſhould ſhew—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Contemne it:
His envie faines this, and he's but reporter,
Without a ſecond, of his owne dry fancies.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Yes Madam, the whole City ſpeakes it with me,
And though it may diſtaſte, 'tis certaine you
Are brought into the ſceane, and with him cenſur'd;
For you are given out for the provident Lady,
That not to be unfurniſh'd for her pleaſures
(As without them to what vaine uſe is greatneſſe)
Have made choyce of an able man, a young man
Of an Herculean back to doe you ſervice,
And one you may command too, that is active,
And does what you would have him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are foule mouth'd.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: That can ſpeake well, write Verſes too, and good ones,
Sharp and conceited, whoſe wit you may lie with
When his performance failes him; one you have
Maintain'd abroad to learne new waies to pleaſe you.
And by the gods you well reward him for it,
No night (in which while you lye ſick and panting)
He watches by you but is worth a tallent:
No conference in your Coach which is not paid with
A ſcarlet Suit; this the poore people mutter,
Though I beleeve, for I am bound to doe ſo,
A Lady of your youth, that feeds high too,
And a moſt exact Lady, may doe all this
Out of vertuous love, the laſt bought vizard
That Leachery purchas'd.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Not a word beyond this,
The reverence I owe to that one wombe
In which we both were embrions, makes me ſuffer
What's paſt; but if continued—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay your hand,
The Queene ſhall right mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let him doe it,
It is but marrying him; and for your anger
Know that I ſlight it: when your Goddeſſe here
Is weary of your ſacrifice, as ſhe will be,
You know my houſe, and there amongſt my ſervants
Perhaps youl finde a livery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be not mov'd,
I know the rancour of his diſpoſition,
And turne it on himſelfe by laughing at it,
And in that let me teach you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I learne gladly. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Neanthes, Soſines, and Eraton, ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You are met unto my wiſhes, if you ever
Deſir'd true mirth ſo far as to adventure
To dye with the extreamity of laughter,
I come before the object that will doe it;
Or let me live your foole.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Who is't Neanthes?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Lamprias the Uſurers ſonne.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Lamprias? the youth
Of ſix and fifty?

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: That was ſent to travell
By rich Beliza, till he came to age,
And was fit for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: The very ſame,
This gallant with his Guardian, and his Tutor,
(And of the three who is moſt foole I know not)
Are newly come to Corinth, ile not ſtale them
By giving up their characters, but leave you
To make your owne diſcoveries: here they are Sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.l: That legge a little higher; very well.
Now put your face into the Travellors poſture;
Exceeding good.

sp.speaker: Vnckle.
sp.l: Doe you mark how they admire him?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: They will be all my Schollars, when they know
And underſtand him truly.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Phoebus guard me
From this new Python.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: How they have trimm'd him up
Like an old Reveller?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Curl'd him and perfum'd him,
But that was done with judgement, for he lookes
Like one that purg'd perpetually; truſt me,
That Witches face of his is painted too,
And every ditch upon it buries more
Then would ſet off ten Bawds, and all their tenants.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: See how it moves towards us.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: There's a ſalutation:
'Troth Gentlemen, you have beſtowed much travell
In trayning up your Pupill.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Sir, great buildings
Require great labours, which yet we repent not,
Since for the Countries good we have brought home
An abſolute man.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: As any of his yeares,
Corinth can ſhew you.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: He's exceeding meagre.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: His contemplation—

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: Beſides, 'tis fit
Learners ſhould be kept hungry.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You all contemplate;
For three ſuch wretched pictures of leane famine
I never ſaw together.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: We have fat minds Sir,
And travell'd to ſave charges. Doe you thinke
'Twas fit a young and hopefull Gentleman
Should be brought up a glutton? he's my Ward,
Nor was there ever where I bore the bagg
Any ſuperfluous waſte.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Pray you can it ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: He knowes all Languages, but will uſe none,
They are all too big for his mouth, or elſe too little
T'expreſſe his great conceits: and yet of late
With ſome ippulſion he hath ſet downe
In a ſtrange method by the way of queſtion,
And briefly, to all buſineſſe whatſoever
That may concerne a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Good Sir, let's heare him.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Come on Sir.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: They have taught him like an Ape,
To doe his tricks by ſignes: now he begins.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: When ſhall we be drunke together?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: That's the firſt.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Where ſhall we whore to night?

sp.speaker: Ʋncle.
sp.l: That ever followes.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: 'Odds me, he now lookes angry.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Shall we quarrell?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: With me at no hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Then let's proteſt.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Theſe are Sir, the foure new Vertues
That are in faſhion: many a mile we meaſur'd
Before we could arrive unto this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You might have ſpar'd that labour, for at home here
Ther's little elſe in practice: Ha? the Queene?
Good friends, for halfe an houre remove your motion,
To morrow willingly when we have more leaſure
We'l looke on him againe.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Did I not rarely?

sp.speaker: Ʋncle.
sp.l: Excellent well.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: He ſhall have ſixe Plumbs for it. Exeunt.

div.stage: Anter Agenor, Leonidas, Theanor, Queene, Merione, Beliza, Euphanes, Crates, Ladies, atten|dants with Lights.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: How much my Court is honour'd princely Brother
In your vouchaſing it your long'd for preſence
Were tedious to repeat, ſince 'tis already
(And heartily) acknowledg'd; may the gods
That looke into Kings actions ſmile upon
The league we have concluded; and their juſtice
Finde me out to revenge it if I breake
One article.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Great miracle of Queenes,
How happy I eſteeme my ſelfe in being
Thought worthy to be numbred in the rank
Of your confederates, my love and beſt ſervice
Shall teach the world hereafter: but this gift
With which you have confirm'd it, is ſo farre
Beyond my hopes and meanes ere to returne,
That of neceſſity I muſt dye oblig'd
To your unanſwer'd bounty.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The ſweet Lady
In bluſhes gives your Highneſſe thankes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Beleeve it
On the Queenes word, ſhe is a worthy one,
And I am ſo acquainted with her goodneſſe,
That but for this peace that hath chang'd my purpoſe,
And to her more advancement, I ſhould gladly
Have call'd her Daughter.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Though I am depriv'd of
A bleſſing 'tis not in the Fates to equall,
To ſhew my ſelfe a ſubject as a ſonne,
Here I give up my claime, and willingly
With mine owne hand deliver you what once
I lov'd above my ſelfe; and from this houre
(For my affection yeelds now to my duty)
Vow never to ſollicite her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: 'Tis well cover'd
Neanthes, and the reſt. Exit Cra. Nea. Soſ. Era.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay, for this night
You muſt (for 'tis our Country faſhion Sir)
Leave her to her devotions, in the morning
We'l bring you to the Temple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How in this
Your Highneſſe honours me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sweet reſt to all.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: This kiſſe, and I obey you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pleaſe it your Highneſſe,
This is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: You are welcome home Sir,
(Now as I live, one of a promiſing preſence)
I have heard of you before, and you ſhall finde
Ile know you better: finde out ſomething that
May doe you good, and reſt aſſur'd to have it.
Were you at Sparta lately?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Three daies ſince
Madam I came from thence.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: 'Tis very late,
Good night my Lord; doe you Sir follow me,
I muſt talke further with you.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: All reſt with you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Crates, Neanthes, Eraton, Soſicles diſguiz'd.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: She muſt paſſe through this Cloyſter, ſuddainly
And boldly ſeaze upon her.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Where's the Prince?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He does expect us at the place I ſhew'd you.
I heare ones footing, peace, 'tis ſhe;

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now leave me,
I know the way, though Veſta witneſſe with me
I never trod it with ſuch feare: helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Stop her mouth cloſe, out with the Light, ile guide you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: TO whom now ſhall I cry? What pow'r thus kneele to?
And beg my raviſht honour back upon me?
Deafe, deafe, you gods of goodneſſe, deafe to me,
Deafe Heaven to all my cryes; deafe hope, deafe juſtice,
I am abus'd, and you that ſee all ſaw it;
Saw it, and ſmil'd upon the villaine did it:
Saw it, and gave him ſtrength: why have I pray'd to ye,
When all the worlds eyes have been ſunk in ſlumbers?
Why have I then powr'd out my teares? kneel'd to ye?
And from the Altar of a pure heart ſent ye
Thoughts like, your ſelves, white, innocent, vowes purer
And of a ſweeter flame then all earths odours?
Why have I ſung your praiſes, ſtrew'd your Temples,
And Crown'd your holy Prieſts with Virgin Roſes?
Is it we hold ye powerfull, to deſtroy us?
Beleeve, and honour ye, to ſee us ruin'd?
Theſe teares of anger thus I ſprinckle toward ye,
You that dare ſleep ſecure whilſt Virgins ſuffer,
Theſe ſtick like Comets, blaze eternally,
Till with the wonder they have wak't your juſtice,
And forc't ye feare our curſes, as we yours.
My ſhame ſtill followes me, and ſtill proclames me;
He turnes away in ſcorne, I am contemned too,
A more unmanly violence then the other;
Bitten, and flung away? What ere you are
Sir, you that have abus'd me, and now moſt baſely
And ſacrilegiouſly rob'd this faire Temple,
I fling all theſe behinde me, but looke upon me,
But one kinde loving look, be what ye will,
So from this hower you will be mine, my Husband;
And you his hand in miſchiefe, I ſpeake to you too,
Counſell him nobly now; you know the miſchief,
The moſt unrighteous act he has done, perſwade him,
Perſwade him like a friend, knock at his Conſcience
Till faire Repentance follow: yet be worthy of me,
And ſhew your ſelf, if ever good thought guided ye,
You have had your foul will, make it yet fair with marriage;
Open your ſelf and take me, wed me now: Draws his Dagger.
More fruits of Villany? your Dagger? come
Ye are mercifull, I thank ye for your medicine:
Is that too worthy too?
Devill, thou with him,
Thou penny Bawd to his Luſt, will not that ſtir thee?
Do you work by tokens now? Be ſure I live not,
For your owne ſafeties knaves. I will ſit patiently:
But as ye are true Villaines, the Devills owne ſervants,
And thoſe he loves and truſts, make it as bloody
An Act, of ſuch true horrour Heaven would ſhake at,
'Twill ſhew the braver: goodneſſe hold my hope faſt,
And in thy mercies looke upon my ruines,
And then I am right: my eyes grow dead and heavy:
sp.stage: Enter ſixe diſguis'd, ſinging and dancing to a horrid Muſick, and ſprinkling water on her face.
sp.l: Wrong me no more as ye are men.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is faſt.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Away with her. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Agenor, and Gentlemen with Torches.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Now Gentlemen, the time's come now t'enjoy
That fruitfull happineſſe my heart has long'd for:
This day be happy call'd, and when old Time
Brings it about each yeare, crown'd with that ſweetneſſe
It gives me now, ſee every man obſerve it,
And laying all aſide beares ſhew of buſineſſe,
Give this to joy and triumph: How ſits my cloaths?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Handſome, and wondrous well Sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Do they ſhew richly?
For to thoſe curious eyes even beauty envies,
I muſt not now appeare poore, or low faſhion'd;
Me thinks I am younger then I was, farre younger;
And ſuch a promiſe in my bloud I feele now,
That if there may be a perpetuall youth
Beſtowed on man, I am that ſoule ſhall win it:
Do's my haire ſtand well, Lord how ill-favourdly
You have dreſt me to day? how baldly? why this Cloke?

sp.speaker: 2 G●n.
sp.l: Why 'tis the richeſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: And here ye have put me on
A paire of Breeches look like a paire of Bagpipes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Beleeve Sir, they ſhew bravely.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Why theſe Stockings?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent
sp.l: Your Legg appeares—

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Peuh I would have had 'em peach collour,
All young, and new about me: and this Scarfe here
A goodly thing: you have trickt me like a Puppet.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Ile undertake to rig forth a whole Navie,
And with leſſe labour then one man in love,
They are never pleas'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Me thinks he lookes well.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Well
As man can looke, as handſome: now do I wonder
He found not fault his Noſe was put on ugly,
Or his Eyes lookt too gray, and rayle at us,
They are the waywards things, theſe Lovers.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: All will be right
When once it comes to th' puſh.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: I would they were at it
For our owne quiet ſake.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Come, wait upon me,
And beare your ſelves like mine, my friends, and nobly. Ex.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Theanor, Crates, and Erates, bringing Merione.

sp.speaker: Erat.
sp.l: This is her Brothers Doore.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: There lay her downe then.
Lay her along: ſhe is faſt ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As forgetfulneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Be not you ſtirr'd now, but away to your Mother,
Give all attendance, let no ſtaine appeare
Of feare, or doubt in your face: carry your ſelfe confidently.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But whither runs your drift now?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: When ſhe wakes,
Either what's done will ſhew a meere dreame to her,
And carry no more credit: or ſay ſhe finde it,
Say ſhe remember all the circumſtances,
Twenty to one the ſhapes in which they were acted,
The horrours, and the ſtill affrights we ſhew'd her,
Riſing in wilder figures to her memory
Will run her mad, and no man gheſſe the reaſon:
If all theſe faile, and that ſhe riſe up perfect,
And ſo collect her ſelfe, beleeve this Sir,
Not knowing who it was that did this to her,
Nor having any power to gheſſe; the thing done too,
Being the utter undoing of her Honour
If it be knowne, and to the worlds eye publiſh'd,
Eſpecially at this time when Fortune courts her,
She muſt and will conceale it; nay, forget it,
The woman is no Lucrece; get you gone Sir,
And as you would have more of this ſport, feare not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am confirm'd, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Farewell, away Sir:
Diſperſe your ſelves, and as you love his favour,
And that that crowns it, Gold, no tongues amongſt ye.
You know your charge, this way goes no ſuſpition. Exeu.

div.stage: Enter Agenor and Leonides, with two Gent. with Lights.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: You are ſtirring early Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It was my duty
To wait upon your Grace.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How fares your Siſter,
My beauteous Miſtris, what is ſhe ready yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No doubt ſhe'l loſe no time Sir, yong Maids in her way
Tread upon thornes, and think an houre an age
Till the Prieſt has done his part, that theirs may follow:
I ſaw her not ſince yeſterday ith' evening:
But Sir, I am ſure ſhe is not ſlack; beleeve me,
Your grace will finde a loving ſoule.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: A ſweet one,
And ſo much joy I carry in the thought of it,
So great a happineſſe to know ſhe is mine;
Beleeve me noble Brother, that to expreſſe it
Me thinkes a Tongue's a poore thing, can do nothing,
Imagination leſſe: who's that that lies there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where Sir?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Before the doore, it lookes like a woman:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This way I came abroad, but then there was nothing,
One of the Maids o're-watch'd belike.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: It may be.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But me thinks this is no fit place to ſleep in.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis ſure a woman Sir, ſhe has Jewels on too:
She feares no foule play ſure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bring a Torch hither,
Yet 'tis not perfect day: I ſhould know thoſe Garments.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How ſound ſhe ſleepes?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am ſorry to ſee this.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And you now I am ſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: My Miſtris, how comes this?

div.stage: Enter Queen, Theanor, Beliza, Euphanes, Neanthes, attendants.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Queene and her traine?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: You know my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And will be moſt carefull.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be not long abſent, the ſuit you preferr'd
Is granted.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: This fellow mounts apace, and will
Towre o're us like a Falcon.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Good morrow to ye all, why ſtand ye wondring?
Enter the houſe Sir, and bring out your Miſtris,
You muſt obſerve our Ceremonies: what's the matter?
What's that ye ſtand at? How Merione?
Aſleep i'th ſtreet? belike ſome ſudden Palſie
As ſhe ſtept out laſt night upon devotion,
To tooke her farewell of her Virgin ſtate,
The Ayre being ſharp and piercing, ſtruck her ſuddenly:
See if ſhe breath.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A little.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Wake her then,
'Tis ſure a fit.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: She wakes her ſelfe,
Give roome to her.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: See how the ſpirits ſtruggle to recover,
And ſtrongly re-inforce their ſtrengths; for certaine
This was no naturall ſleep.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am of your minde Madam.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No Sonne, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray Heaven no trick in't;
Good ſoule ſhe little merits ſuch a miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: She is broad awake now, and her ſence clears up,
'Twas ſure a fit; ſtand off.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Queene, my Love here,
And all my noble friends? Why where am I?
How am I traunc'd, and moaped? i'th ſtreet? Heaven bleſſe me,
Shame to my Sex; o'th ground too? O, I remember—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How wilde ſhe lookes?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Oh my cold heart, how ſhe trembles?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O I remember, I remember.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My ſhame, my ſhame, my ſhame: O I remember
My never-dying ſhame.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Here has been villainie.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I feare ſo to.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are no Furies are ye?
No horrid ſhapes ſent to affright me?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: No ſweet,
We are your friends: looke up, I am Agenor,
O my Merione, that loves you dearely:
And come to marry ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Siſter, what ayle ye?
Speake out your griefes, and boldly—

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Something ſticks here
Will choake ye elſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I hope it will.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be free Lady,
You have your loving friends about ye.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Deare Merione,
By the unſpotted love I ever bore ye,
By thine owne goodneſſe—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O 'tis gone, 'tis gone Sir,
I am now I know not what: pray ye look not on me,
No name is left me, nothing to inherit
But that deteſted, baſe, and branded —

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Speake it,
And how; diſeaſes of moſt danger
Their cauſes once diſcover'd are eaſily cur'd:
My faire Merione.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thanke your love Sir;
When I was faire Merione, unſpotted,
Pure, and unblaſted in the bud you honour'd,
White as the heart of truth, then Prince Agenor,
Even then I was not worthy of your favour;
Wretch that I am, leſſe worthy now of pitty:
Let no good thing come neare me, vertue fly me;
You that have honeſt noble names deſpiſe me,
For I am nothing now but a maine peſtilence
Able to poyſon all. Send thoſe unto me
That have forgot their names, ruin'd their fortunes,
Deſpis'd their honours; thoſe that have been Virgins
Raviſh'd and wrongd, and yet dare live to tell it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Now it appeares too plaine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Send thoſe ſad people
That hate the light, and curſe ſociety;
Whoſe thoughts are Graves, and from whoſe eyes continually
Their melting ſoules drop out, ſend thoſe to me;
And when their ſorrowes are moſt excellent,
So full that one griefe more cannot be added,
My Story like a torrent ſhall devoure 'em.
Hark, it muſt out; but pray ſtand cloſe together,
And let not all the world heare.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Speake it boldly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And Royall Lady, think but charitably,
Your Grace has known my breeding.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Prethee ſpeake it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is there no ſtranger here? ſend off your ſervants,
And yet it muſt be knowne: I ſhake.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Sweet Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am abus'd, baſely abus'd; do you gheſſe yet?
Come cloſe ile tell ye plainer; I am Whor'd,
Raviſh'd, and robb'd of Honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O the Divell.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: What helliſh Slave was this?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A wretch, a wretch,
A damned wretch: do you know the Villaine Lady?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not by gheſſe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O no.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It muſt be knowne.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Where was the place?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know not neither.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: O Heaven,
Is this the happy time? my hope to this come?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Neither the man, nor circumſtances?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: His tongue,
Did you not heare his tongue, no voice?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: None, none Sir:
All I know of him was his violence.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How came ye hither Sweet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know not neither.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A cunning piece of Villany.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: All I remember
Is onely this: Going to Veſtas Temple
To give the Goddeſſe my laſt Virgin prayers,
Neere to that place I was ſuddenly ſurpris'd,
By five or ſixe diſguis'd, and from thence violently
To my diſhonour hal'd: that Act perform'd,
Brought back, but how, or whether, till I wak'd here.—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is ſo monſtrous the gods cannot ſuffer it;
I have not read in all the villanies
Committed by the moſt obdurate Raſcalls,
An act ſo truly impious.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Would I knew him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: He muſt be known, the Devill cannot hide him.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: If all the Art I have, or power can do it,
He ſhall be found, and ſuch a way of juſtice
Inflicted on him: A Lady wrong'd in my Court,
And this way rob'd, and ruin'd?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be contented Madam,
If he be above ground I will have him.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Faire vertuous Maid, take comfort yet and flouriſh,
In my love flouriſh: the ſtaine was forc'd upon ye
None of your wills, nor yours; riſe, and riſe mine ſtill,
And riſe the ſame white, ſweet, faire ſoule, I lov'd ye,
Take me the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I kneele and thank ye Sir,
And I muſt ſay ye are truly honourable,
And dare confeſſe my will yet ſtill a Virgin;
But ſo unfit and weak a Cabinet
To keep your love and vertue in am I now,
That have been forc'd and broken, loſt my luſtre,
I meane this body, ſo corrupt a Volume
For you to ſtudy goodneſſe in, and honour,
I ſhall intreat your Grace, conferre that happineſſe
Upon a beauty ſorrow never ſaw yet:
And when this griefe ſhall kill me, as it muſt do,
Only remember yet ye had ſuch a Miſtris;
And if ye then dare ſhed a teare, yet honour me:
Good Gentlemen expreſſe your pitties to me,
In ſeeking out this villany; and my laſt ſuit
Is to your Grace, that I may have your favour
To live a poore recluſe Nun with this Lady,
From Court and Company, till Heaven ſhall heare me,
And ſend me comfort, or death end my miſery.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Take your own will, my very heart bleeds for thee.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Farewell Merione, ſince I have not thee
Ile wed thy goodneſſe, and thy memory.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I her faire revenge.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Away: let's follow it,
For he is ſo rank i'th wind we cannot miſſe him. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Conon you are welcome home, yee are wondrous welcome,
Is this your firſt arrivall?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, but now
I reacht the Towne.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ye'ar once more welcome then.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I thanke ye noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Pray ye do me the honour
To make my poore houſe firſt—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray Sir excuſe me,
I have not ſeene mine owne yet; nor made happy
Theſe longing eyes with thoſe I love there: what's this a Taverne?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo by the outſide.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Step in here then,
And ſince it offers it ſelfe ſo freely to us,
A place made only for liberall entertainment,
Let's ſeeke no further but make uſe of this,
And after the Greek faſhion, to our friends,
Crown a round cup or two.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your pleaſure Sir.
Drawers, who waits within?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Look into the Lilly-pot: why Mark there;
You are welcome Gentlemen; heartily welcome
My noble friend.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let's have good Wine mine Hoſt,
And a fine private roome.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Will ye be there Sir?
What is't you'l drink? ile draw your Wine my ſelfe:
Quiſſions ye knaves: why when?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Chios, or Lebos, Greek?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your beſt and neateſt.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Ile draw ye that ſhall dance.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Away, be quick then. Exit Vintner.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: How does your Brother Sir, my noble friend
The good Euphanes? in all my courſe of travell
I met not with a Gentleman ſo furniſh'd
In gentleneſſe and courteſie; beleeve Sir,
So many friendly Offices I receiv'd from him,
So great, and timely, and enjoy'd his company
In ſuch an open and a liberall ſweetneſſe,
That when I dare forget him—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He's in good health Sir,
But you will finde him a much alter'd man,
Growne a great Courtier Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: A man drawne up, that leaves no print behind him
Of what he was: thoſe goodneſſes you ſpeake of
That have been in him, thoſe that you call freedomes,
Societies, and ſweetneſſe, looke for now Sir,
You'le finde no ſhadowes of them left, no ſound,
The very Ayre he has liv'd in alter'd: now behold him,
And you ſhall ſee a thing walk by, looke big upon ye,
And cry for place; I am the Queenes, give roome there:
If you bow low, may be he'l touch the Bonnet,
Or fling a forced ſmile at ye for a favour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He is your brother Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Theſe formes put off,
Which travell, and Court Holy-water ſprinkle on him,
I dare accept, and know him: you'l think it ſtrange Sir,
That even to me, to me his naturall Brother,
And one by birth he owes a little honour too—
(But that's all one) come give me ſome Wine, mine Hoſt,
Here's to your faire returne.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I wonder at it,
But ſure he has found a nature not worth owning
In this way; elſe I know he is tender carried.
I thank ye Sir: and now durſt I preſume
For all you tell me of theſe alterations,
And ſtops in his ſweet nature, which till I finde ſo,
I have known him now ſo long, & look'd ſo through him,
You muſt give me leave to be a little faithleſſe:
I ſay for all theſe, if you pleaſe to venter
Ile lay the Wine we drink, let me ſend for him
(Even I that am the pooreſt of his fellowſhip)
But by a Boy oth' houſe too, let him have buſineſſe,
Let him attend the Queene, nay let his Miſtris
Hold him betwixt her armes, he ſhall come to me,
And ſhall drink with me too; love me, and heartily,
Like a true honeſt man bid me welcome home.
I am confident.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You will loſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You'l ſtand toth' wager?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Go Boy, and tell Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He's now gone up the ſtreet Sir,
With a great traine of Gallants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: What think you now Sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Go, and overtake him,
Commend my love unto him: my name is Conon,
Tell him I am new arriv'd, and where I am,
And would requeſt to ſee him preſently:
Ye ſee I uſe old dudgen phraſe to draw him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ile hang and quarter when you draw him hether.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am gone Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Here's to you now,
And you ſhall finde his travell has not ſtopt him
As you ſuppoſe, nor alter'd any freedome,
But made him far more cleare and excellent;
It drawes the groſneſſe off the underſtanding,
And renders active and induſtrious ſpirits:
He that knowes moſt mens manners, muſt of neceſſity
Beſt know his owne, and mend thoſe by example:
'Tis a dull thing to travell like a Mill-horſe,
Still in the place he was borne in, lam'd and blinded;
Living at home is like it: pure and ſtrong ſpirits
That like the Fire ſtill covet to fly upward,
And to give fire as well as take it; caſ'd up, and mewd here
I meane at home, like luſty metled Horſes,
Onely ty'd up in Stables, to pleaſe their Maſters,
Beat out their fiery lives in their owne Litters,
Why doe not you travell Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I have no beliefe in't
I ſee ſo many ſtrange things, halfe unhatcht, to
Returne, thoſe that went out men, and good men,
They looke like potch'd Eggs with the ſoules ſuckt out,
Empty and full of wind: all their affections
Are bak'd in Rye cruſt, to hold carriage
From this good Towne toth' other: and when they are open'd,
They are ſo ill cooked and mouldy—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ye are pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ile ſhew ye a pack of theſe: I have 'em for ye,
That have been long in travell too.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pleaſe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You know the Merchants walk, Boy?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: And you remember thoſe Gentlemen were here
The other day with me?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Then go thither,
For there I am ſure they are, pray 'em come hither,
(And uſe my name) I would be glad to ſee 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: Your Brother's comming in Sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Odds my paſſion,
Out with the Plate ye knaves: bring the new Quiſhions,
And waſh thoſe Glaſſes I ſet by for high dayes,
Perfume the roomes along, why Sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Bid my Wife make her ſelfe ready handſomely,
And put on her beſt Apron: it may be
The noble Gentleman will looke upon her.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Where is he Boy?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: Your worſhip's heartily welcome,
It joyes my very heart to ſee ye here Sir.
The Gentleman that ſent for your Honour—

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: O good mine Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.l: To my poor homely houſe, and't like your honor.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I thank thine honour good mine Hoſt, where is he?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What think ye now? my beſt Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Conon, welcome my friend, my noble friend how is it?
are you in ſafety come, in health?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: All health, all ſafety,
Riches, and all that makes content and happineſſe
Now I am here I have: how have you far'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Well, I thank Heaven, and never nearer friend
To catch at great occaſion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Indeed I joy in't.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Nor am I for my ſelfe borne in theſe fortunes,
In truth I love my friends.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You were noble ever.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I thought you have not knowne me.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yes, ye are my Brother,
My elder Brother too, would your affections
Were able but to aske that love I owe to ye,
And as I give, preſerve it: here friend Conon,
To your faire welcome home.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Deare Sir, I thank ye,
Fill it toth' brim, Boy: Crates.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ile pledge you,
But for that glorious Comet lately fired.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Fie, fie Sir, fie.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Nay, let him take his freedomes,
He ſtirs not me I vow to ye: much leſſe ſtaines me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot talke with that neat travelling tongue.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As I live, he has the worſt beleefe in men abroad.
I am glad I am come home.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Here are the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: O let 'em enter: now you that truſt in travell,
And make ſharp Beards, and little Breeches Deities,
You that inhaunce the daily price of Tooth-picks,
And hold there is no homebred hapineſſe,
Behold a modell of your minds and actions.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Though this be envious, yet done ith' way of mirth,
I am content to thank ye for't.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis well yet.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let the Maske enter.

div.stage: Enter Onos, his Ʋnckle and Tutor.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: A pretty Taverne 'faith, of a fine ſtructure.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: Beare your ſelfe like a Gentleman, here's ſix pence,
And be ſure you breake no Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Harke ye Pupill,
Go as I taught you, hang more upon your hams,
and put your knees out bent: there, yet a little:
Now I beſeech ye, be not ſo improvident
To forget your travelling pace, 'tis a maine poſture,
And to all unayr'd Gentlemen will betray you:
Play with your Piſa Beard: why, where's your bruſh Pupil?
He muſt have a Bruſh Sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: More charge yet?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Here, take mine,
Theſe elements of travell he muſt not want Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Ma' foy, he has had ſome nineteene pence in elements,
What would you more?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What Mounſieur Onos, the very pump of travell,
Sir, as I live you have done me the greateſt kindneſſe,
O my faire Sir, Lampree, the carefull Unckle
To this young hopefull iſſue; Mounſieur Tutor too,
The father to his minde; Come, come, let's hug Boyes,
Why what a bunch of travell doe I embrace now,
Me thinkes I put a Girdle about Europe;
How has the Boy profited?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: He has enough Sir,
If his too fiery mettle doe not mar it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is he not thrifty yet?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: That's all his fault,
Too bounteous minded being under age too,
A great conſumer of his ſtock in Pippins▪
Had ever a hot ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come hither Onos,
Will you love me for this fine Apple?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: We.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And will ye be rul'd by me ſometimes?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: 'Faith I will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That's a good Boy.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: Pray give me not the childe ſo much fruit,
He's of a raw Complexion.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You Mounſieur hard egge,
Do you remember me? Doe you remember
When you and your Conſort travell'd through Hungary?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's in that circuit ſtill.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Do you remember
The cantell of immortall Cheeſe ye carried with ye,
The halfe cold Cabbedge, in a leather Sachell,
And thoſe invincible Eggs that would lye in your bowells
A fortnight together, and then turne to bedſtaves;
Your ſowre milk that would choak an Iriſh man,
And bread was bak'd in Caeſars time for the Army?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Providence, providence.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: The ſoule of travell.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Can the Boy ſpeak yet?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Yes, and as fine a Gentleman,
I thanke my able knowledge, he has arriv'd at,
Only a little ſparing of his Language,
Which every man of obſervation—

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: And of as many tongues.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Pray be content Sir,
You know you are for the bodily part, the Purſe,
I for the magazine, the minde.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Come hither ſpringall.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: That in the Almain Tongue ſignifies a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fuph.
sp.p: What think you of the formes of Italy or Spain?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: I love mine owne Country Pippin.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Nobly anſwer'd,
Borne for his Country firſt.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: A great Philoſopher:
What Horſes do you prefer?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: The White horſe Sir,
There were I lye; honeſt and a juſt beaſt,

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: O Caput lepidum: a Childe to ſay this,
Are theſe figures for the mouthes of Infants?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Onos, what wenches?
Come, tell me true.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeake without booke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: When ſhall we have one, ha?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: Steale me from mine Unckle,
For looke you, I am broke out horribly
For want of fleſhly Phiſick: they ſay I am too yong,
And that 'twill ſpoyle my growth▪ but could you help me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Meet me to morrow man, no more.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You thinke now
Ye have open'd ſuch a ſhame to me of travell,
By ſhewing theſe thin Cubbs: ye have honour'd us
Againſt your will, proclam'd us excellent:
Three Frailes of Sprats carried from Mart, to Mart,
Are as much meat as theſe, to more uſe travell'd;
A bunch of bloted fooles: me thinkes your judgement
Should looke abroad ſometimes without your envie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Such are moſt of you: ſo I take my leave,
And when you finde your womens favour faile,
'Tis ten to one yoa'l know your ſelfe, and ſeeke me
Upon a better Muſter of your manners.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is not hanſome Sir.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Pray take your pleaſure,
You wound the wind as much—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Come you with me,
I have buſineſſe for you preſently: there's for your Wine,
I muſt confeſſe I loſt it.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: Shall I ſteale to ye
And ſhall we ſee the Wench?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A dainty one.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: And have a diſh of Pippins?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What a peck man.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Will you wait Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray let's meet oftner Gentlemen,
I would not loſe ye.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: O ſweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Do you thinke I would,
Such noted men as you?

sp.speaker: Onos, Ʋnc. Tut.
sp.l: We are your Servants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That thing they would keep in everlaſting nonage,
My Brother for his owne ends has thruſt on
Upon my Miſtris, 'tis true, he ſhall be rich
If ever he can get that Rogue his Unckle
To let him be of yeares to come to inherit it,
Now what the maine drift is—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Say ye ſo? no more words,
Ile keepe him company till he be of yeares,
Though it be a hundred yeares, but ile diſcover it;
And ten to one ile croſſe it too.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You are honeſt,
And I ſhall ſtudy ſtill your love: farewell Sir,
For theſe few houres I muſt deſire your pardon,
I have buſineſſe of importance: once a day
At leaſt I hope you'l ſee me: I muſt ſee you elſe:
So, once more ye are welcome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: All my thankes Sir,
And when I leave to love you, life go from me. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: WHy Sir, the Kingdomes his, and no man now
Can come to Corinth, or from Corinth goe
Without his Licence; he puts up the tithes
Of every Office through Achaia;
From Courtier to the Carter hold of him:
Our Lands, our Liberties, nay very lives
Are ſhut up in his Cloſet, and let looſe
But at his pleaſure; Bookes, and all diſcourſe
Have now no Patron, nor direction.
But glorifi'd Euphanes: our Cups are guilty
That quench our thirſts, if not unto his health:
Oh, I could eat my heart, and fling away
My very ſoule for anguiſh: gods, nor men
Should tollerate ſuch diſproportion.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And yet is he belov'd: whether't be vertue,
Or ſeeming vertue which he makes the cloake
To his ambition.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Be it which it will:
Your Highneſſe is to tame, your eyes too film'd
To ſee this, and ſit ſtill: the Lion ſhould not
Tremble to heare the bellowing of the Bull;
Nature excuſe me, though he be my Brother,
You are my Countries Father, therefore mine:
One paralell line of Love I bend on him,
All lines of love and duty meet in you
As in their Center: therefore heare, and weigh
What I ſhall ſpeake: You know the Queen your Mother
Did from a private ſtate your Father raiſe,
So all your Royalty you hold from her;
She is older then ſhe was, therefore more doating,
And what know we but blindneſſe of her love
(That hath from underneath the foot of fortune
Set, even Euphanes foot, on fortunes head)
Will take him by the hand, and cry, Leap now
Into my bed; 'tis but a trick of age;
Nothing impoſſible.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What do you infer on this?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your pardon Sir:
With reverence to the Queen; yet why ſhould I
Feare to ſpeak plaine what pointeth to your good?
A Good old Widow is a hungry thing,
(I ſpeak of other Widows, not of Queens.)

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Speak to thy purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I approach it: Sir,
Should young Euphanes claſpe the Kingdome thus,
And pleaſe the good old Lady ſome one night;
What might not ſhe be wrought to put on you,
Quite to ſupplant your birth? neither is ſhe
Paſt children, as I take it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Crates, Thou ſhak'ſt me;
Thou, that doſt hate thy Brother for my love,
In my love finde one; henceforth be my brother:
This Gyant I will fell beneath the earth;
I will ſhine out, and melt his artfull wings:
Euphanes, from my mothers ſea of favours
Spreads like a River, and runs calmly on,
Secure yet from my ſtormes; like a young pine
He growes up planted under a faire Oake,
Whoſe ſtrong large branches yet do's ſhelter him,
And every Traveller admires his beauty;
But like a winde, ile work into his crancks,
Trouble his ſtreame, and drowne all Veſſells that
Ride on his Greatneſſe: under my mothers armes,
Like to a ſtealing tempeſt will I ſearch,
And rend his root from her protection.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I, now Theanor ſpeaks like Prince Theanor.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But how ſhall we provoke him to our ſnares?
He has a temper malice cannot move
To exceed the bounds of judgement; he is ſo wiſe,
That we can pick no cauſe to affront him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: No?
What better then his croſſing your intent?
The ſuit I had to ye? Conons forfeit ſtate
(Before he travel'd) for a Riot, he
Hath from your Mother got reſtor'd to him:

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Durſt he? What is this Conon?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: One that hath,
As people ſay, in forraigne pleaſur'd him.
sp.stage: Enter Onos, Ʋncle, Tutor, Neanthes, Soſicles, Eraton.
sp.l: But now no more;
They have brought the Travellors I told you of,
That's the ſweet youth, that is my Brothers Rivall,
That curles his head, for he has little haire,
And paints his vizor, for it is no face,
That ſo deſires to follow you, my Lord:
Show 'em ſome countenance, and it will beget
Our ſport at leaſt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What villanous Crab-tree legs he makes?
His ſhins are full of true-love knots.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: His leggs were ever villanous, ſince I knew him.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Faith his Uncles ſhanks are ſomewhat the better.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: But is't poſſible he ſhould believe he is not of age?
He is 50, man, in's Jubile I warrant: s'light, he
Looks older then a groat, the very ſtamp on's face is why
Worne out with handling.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Why I tell you all men believe it when they heare him ſpeake,
He utters ſuch ſingle matter in ſo infantly a voice.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He looks as like a fellow that I have ſeen accommodate
Gentlemen with Tobacco in our Theaters.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Moſt illuſtrious Prince.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: A pox on him, he is guelt, how he trebles?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: I am a Gentleman a both ſides.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: He meanes (ſo't pleaſe your highneſſe) both by Fa|ther & Mother.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Thou a Gentleman? thou an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He is nere the farther from being a Getl. I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your Grace, I am another.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He is another Aſſe he ſaies, I believe him.

sp.speaker: Ʋncle.
sp.l: We be three, Heroicall Prince.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Nay then we muſt have the Picture of 'em, and the
Word Nos ſumus.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: That have travail'd all parts of the Globe together.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.p: For my part, I have ſeen the viciſſitude of fortune before.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: Peace Ʋncle, for though you ſpeak a little better then I—

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: 'Tis a very little, in truth.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Yet we muſt both give place, as they ſay, to the beſt Speaker
The Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Yet ſince it hath pleas'd your radience to decline ſo low, as on us,
Poore and unworthy dunghils.—

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: What a ſtinking knaves this?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Our Perigrination was nere ſo felicitated, as ſince we enter'd the line of your gracious favour, under whoſe bea-my aſpect, and by which infallible Mathematicall com|paſſe, may we but hereafter preſume to ſaile, our induſtries have reach't their deſir'd termination and period; and we ſhall voluntarily ſacrifice our lives to your reſplendent eyes, both the Altars and fires of our devoted offrings.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Oh divine Tutor!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Can you hold Sir?

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p: He ha's ſpoken this very ſpeech to ſome Whore in Corinth.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: A plague on him for a ſuſtain Dictionary; on my conſcience this is the Ʋliſſean Travellor that ſent home his Image riding upon Elephants to the great Magoll.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.p: The ſame: his wit is ſo huge, nought but an Ele|phant could carry him.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: So heavy you meane.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: Theſe three, are ev'n the fineſt one foole tripartite, that was ere diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Or a Treatiſe of famine divided into three branches.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: The Prince ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I thank ye for your loves; but as I told you,
I have ſo little meanes, to do for thoſe
Few followers I have already, that
I would have none ſhiprack themſelves, and fortune,
Upon my barren ſhelf: Sue to Euphanes.
For he is Prince, and Queen, I would have no man
Curſe me in his old age.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Alas Sir, they deſire to follow you
But a farre off, the farther off the better.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I Sir, and't be ſeven mile off, ſo we may but follow you, onely to countenance us in the confronts and af|fronts, which (according to your Highneſſe will) we meane on all occaſions to put upon the Lord Eu|phanes.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: He ſhall not want gibing nor jeering, I warrant him; if he do, i'le forſweare wit.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: It has forſworne thee, 'ile ſweare, it is the ancient enemy to thy houſe.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo; I here receive ye, for my followers a great way off.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Seven miles, my Lord, no further.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: By what time, Sir, (by this meaſure) may I come to follow him in his Chamber?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Why when his Chamber, Sir, is ſeven miles long.

div.stage: Enter Euphanes, Conon, Page, Gent. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Make way there, for my Lord Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Looke Sir, Jove appeares,
The Peacock of our State, that ſpreads a traine
Brighter then Iris bluſhes after raine.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You need not thank me Conon, in your love
You Antidated what I can do for you,
And I in gratitude was bound to this,
And am to much more: and what ere he be
Can with unthankfulneſſe aſſoile me, let him
Dig out mine eyes, and ſing my name in verſe▪
In Balland verſe at every drinking-houſe,
And no man be ſo charitable to lend me
A Dogg to guide my ſteps.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Haile to Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Soſ.
sp.l: Mighty Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: The great Prince Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Key of the Court, and Jewell of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: Sol in our Firmament.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Pearl in the States eye.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Being a black man.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Miſtris of the Land.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Our humble, humble poore Petitions are,
That we may hold our places.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: May we?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yes; be you malicious knaves ſtill: and you fooles.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is the Princes, and your Brothers ſpight.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I know't, but will not know't it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yonder they are,
Who's fine childe's this?

sp.speaker: Ʋnc.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Unckle, le' be,
Let him alone, he is a mighty Prince.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I aske your Highneſſe pardon: I proteſt
By Jupiter I ſaw you not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Humh, it may be ſo,
You have rais'd ſuch mountaines 'twixt your eyes and me,
That I am hidden quite: what do ye meane Sir?
You much forget your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I ſhould much more,
Not to remember my due duty to your Grace;
I know not wherein I have ſo tranſgreſſ'd
My ſervice to your Highneſſe, to deſerve
This rigour and contempt, not from you only
But from your followers, with the beſt of whom
I was an equall in my loweſt ebbe:
Beſeech you Sir, reſpect me as a Gentleman,
I will be never more in heart to you:
Five faire Diſcents I can derive my ſelfe,
From Fathers worthy both in Arts and Armes.
I know your goodneſſe companies your greatneſſe
But that you are perverted: Royall Sir,
I am your humbleſt ſubject, uſe your pleaſure,
But do not give protection to the wrongs
Of theſe ſubordinate Slaves, whom I could cruſh
By that great deſtin'd favour, which my Miſtris
And your majeſtick Mother deignes to me,
But in reſpect of you: I know leane envie
Waites ever on the ſteps of vertue advanc'd:
But why your Mothers grace gets me diſgrace,
Or renders me a ſlave to beare theſe wrongs
I do not know.
Oh Mediocrity,
Thou prizeleſſe jewell, only meane men have
But cannot value; like the precious Jem,
Found in the Mukhill by the ignorant Cock.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your creamy words but cozen: how durſt you
Intercept me ſo lately to my Mother?
And what I meant your Brother, you obtain'd
Unto the forfeiture againe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your anſwer to that my Lord, my Brother.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: May I periſh
If ere I heard you intended ſuch a Suit,
Though 'twould have ſtuck an ignominious brand
Vpon your Highneſſe, to have given your ſervant
A Gentlemans whole ſtate of worth and quality,
Confiſcate only for a youthfull brawle.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your rudiments are too ſawcy: teach your Page.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I, ſo are all things but your flatterers.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Hold you your prating.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You know where you are, you fleeten face.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yet Sir to appeaſe and ſatisfie your anger,
Take what you pleaſe from me, and give it him
In lieu of this: you ſhall not take it neither,
I freely will impart it, halfe my ſtate,
Which Brother if you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Ile ſtarve in Chaines firſt,
Eat my owne armes.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Oh that you ſaw your ſelfe:
You ne're made me ſuch offer in my pooreneſſe,
And 'cauſe (to do you eaſe) I ſought not to you
You thus maligne me; yet your nature muſt not
Corrupt mine, nor your rude examples lead me:
If mine can mend you, I ſhall joy; you know
I feare you not: you have ſeene me prov'd a man
In every way of fortune, 'tis my comfort
I know no more ſuch Brothers in the world
As Crates is.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nor I ſuch as Euphanes:
The temper of an Angell raignes in thee.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Your Royall Mother Sir, (I had forgot)
Entreates your preſence.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You have done her errand,
I may do yours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let it be truth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Crates, ile queſtion you for this.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Piſh, your worſt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away you hounds after your ſent.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Come, we'l ſcorn to talk to 'm: now they are gone,
We'l away too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why beare you this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: To ſhew the paſſive fortitude the beſt;
Vertues a ſolid Rock, whereat being aym'd
The keeneſt darts of envie, yet unhurt
Her Marble Heroes ſtand, built of ſuch Baſes,
Whilſt they recoyle, and wound the Shooters faces.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My Lord, the Queene.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Gentle Euphanes, how,
How do'ſt thou honeſt Lord? oh how I joy
To ſee what I have made, like a choyce Workman,
That having fram'd a Maſter-peece, doth reape
An univerſall comendations.
Princes are Gods in this. Ile build thee yet,
(The good foundation ſo pleaſes me)
A ſtory or two higher; let Doggs barke,
They are fooles that hold them dignifi'd by blood,
They ſhould be only made great that are good.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Oraculous Madam.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sirra, I was thinking
If I ſhould marry thee, what merry tales
Our neighbour Iſlands would make of us;
But let that paſſe, you have a Miſtris
That would forbid our Banes: troth I have wiſh'd
A thouſand times that I had been a man,
Then I might ſit a day with thee alone,
And talke,
But as I am I muſt not; there's no skill
In being good, but in not being thought ill.
Sirrah, who's that?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: So't pleaſe your Majeſty
Conon, the friend I ſu'd for.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: 'Tis diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Gracious Madam,
I owe the gods and you my life.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I thanke you,
I thank you heartily; and I do think you
A very honeſt man, he ſayes you are:
But now ile chide thee; what's the cauſe my Son,
For my eye's every where, and I have heard,
So inſolently do's thee Contumelies
Paſt ſufferance (I am told) yet you complaine not,
As if my juſtice were ſo partiall
As not to right the meaneſt: credit me,
Ile call him to a ſtrict accompt, and fright
By his example, all that dare curb me
In any thing that's juſt: I ſent you for him.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Humbly he did returne, he would wait on you:
But let me implore your Majeſty, not to give
His Highneſſe any check, for worthleſſe me;
They are Court canckers, and not Counſellors
That thus informe you: they do but hate the Prince,
And would ſubvert me: I ſhould curſe my fortune
Even at the higheſt, to be made the ginne
To unſcrew a Mothers love unto her Son:
Better had my pale flame in humble ſhades
Been ſpent unſeene, then to be rais'd thus high,
Now to be thought a meteor to the State,
Portending ruine and contagion:
Beſeech you then reſt ſatisfi'd, the Prince
Is a moſt noble natur'd Gentleman,
And never did to me but what I tooke
As favours from him, my blown billowes muſt not
Strive 'gainſt my ſhore, that ſhould confine me; nor
Juſtle with Rocks to break themſelves to peeces.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Well, thou'rt the compoſition of a god:
My Lion, Lamb, my Eaglet, and my Dove,
Whoſe ſoule runs clearer then Dianas Fount,
Nature pick'd ſeverall flowers from her choyce banks
And bound 'em up in thee, ſending thee forth
A Poſie for the boſome of a Queene.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The Prince attends you.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Farewell my good Lord,
My honeſt man; Stay, haſt no other ſuit?
I prethee tell me; Sirrah, thine eye ſpeakes
As if thou hadſt: out with it modeſt foole.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: With favour Madam, I would crave your leave
To Marry, where I am bound in gratitude,
The immediat meanes ſhe was to all my being:
Nor do I think your wiſedome ſacred Queen
Fetters in favours, taking from me ſo
The liberty that meaneſt men enjoy.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: To marry? you are a foole: thou'ſt anger'd me:
Leave me, ile think on't: Exit Euph. and Conon.
Only to try thee this, for though I love thee,
I can ſubdue my ſelfe: but ſhe that can
Enjoy thee, doth enjoy more then a man.
Nay riſe without a bleſſing, or kneele ſtill:
What's Sir the reaſon you oppoſe me thus,
And ſeeke to darken what I would have ſhine?
Ecclipſe a fire much brighter then thy ſelfe,
Making your Mother not a competent Judge
Of her owne actions?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Gracious Madam, I
I have done no more then what in royalty
(And to preſerve your fame) was fit to do:
Heard you the peoples talke of you, and him
You favour ſo, his greatneſſe, and your love,
The pitty given to me, you would excuſe me,
They prate as if he did diſhonour you:
And what know I, but his owne laviſh tongue
Has utter'd ſome ſuch ſpeeches; he is call'd
The King of Corinth.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: They are traitors all:
I weare a Chriſtall caſement 'fore my heart,
Through which each honeſt eye may looke in to't:
Let it be proſpect unto all the world,
I care not this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This muſt not be my way;
Your pardon gracious Madam: theſe incitements
Made me not ſhew ſo cleare a countenance
Upon the Lord Euphanes as I would:
Which ſince your Majeſty affects ſo grievouſly
Ile cleare the black cloud of it, and henceforth
Uow on this knee all love and grace to him.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Riſe with my bleſſing, and to prove this true,
Beare him from me this Cabinet of Jewells
In your owne perſon, tell him, for his marrying
He may diſpoſe him how, and when he pleaſe. Exit Quee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſhall diſcharge my duty and your will.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I have heard all my Lord, how luckely
Fate pops her very ſpindle in our hands:
This marriage with Beliza you ſhall croſſe,
Then have I one attempt for Lamprias more
Upon this Phaeton: where's Merione's Ring,
That in the Rape you tooke from her?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: In and effect our purpoſe: you my Lord
Shall diſobey your Mothers charge, and ſend
This Cabinet by ſome ſervant of her owne,
That what ſucceeds may have no reference
Unto your Highneſſe.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: On, my engine on.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Now, if we be not ſtruck by Heavens owne hand,
We'l ruine him, and on his ruines ſtand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Theſe heavie Ayres feed ſorrow in her Lady,
And nouriſh it too ſtrongly; like a Mother
That ſpoiles her Childe with giving on't the will.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Some lighter note. A lighter Song.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How like a hill of Snow ſhe ſits, and melts
Before the unchaſt fire of others luſt?
What heart can ſee her paſſion and not break?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Take comfort gentle Madam; you know well
Even actuall ſins committed without will,
Are neither ſins nor ſhame, much more compell'd;
Your Honour's no whit leſſe, your Chaſtity
No whit impair'd, for faire Merione
Is more a Virgin yet then all her Sex:
Alas, 'tis done; why burne theſe Tapers now?
Wicked and frantick Creatures joy in night.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Imagine faire Merione had dream'd
She had been raviſh'd, would ſhe ſi● thus then
Excruciate?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fye, fye, how fond is this?
What reaſon for this ſurfet of remorſe?
How many that have done ill, and proceed,
Women that take degrees in wantonneſſe,
Commence, and riſe in rudiments of Luſt,
That feele no ſcruple of this tenderneſſe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nor are you matches in miſhap, even I
Doe beare an equall part of miſery;
That love, belov'd, a man, the Crowne of men,
Whom I have friended, and how rais'd 'tis better
That all doe know and ſpeak it then my ſelfe:
When he ſail'd low I might have made him mine,
Now at his full gale, it is queſtionable
If ever I o're-take him.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Wherefore ſits
My Phebe ſhadowed in a ſable could?
Thoſe pearly drops which thou lets't fall like beades,
Numbring on them thy veſtall Oriſons
Alas are ſpent in vaine: I love thee ſtill,
In mid'ſt of all theſe ſhowres thou ſweetlier ſent'ſt,
Like a green Meadow on an April day,
In which the Sun and Weſt-wind play together,
Striving to catch and drink the balmy drops.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Lord Euphanes Madam. Exit Mer.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Poore Merione,
She loathes the light, and men. Exit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: The vertuous gods preſerve my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O my moſt honour'd Lord, thoſe times are chang'd.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let times and men change, could Heaven change, Euphanes
Should never change, to be devoted ever
To faire Beliza, ſhould my load of honours,
Or any Grace which you were Author of
Detract mine honour, and diminiſh Grace?
The gods forbid: you here behold your Servant,
Your Creature, gentle Lady, whoſe ſound ſleepes
You purchas'd for him: whoſe food you paid for,
Whoſe garments were your charge, whoſe firſt preferment
You founded: then, what ſince the gracious Queene
Hath, or can reare, is upon your free Land,
And you are Miſtris of.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mock me not gentle Lord,
You ſhine now in too high a ſpheare for me,
We are Plannets now disjoyn'd for ever: yet
Poore ſuperſtitious innocent that I am,
Give leave that I may lift my hands, and love
Not in Idolatry, but perfect zeale:
For credit me, I repent nothing I have done,
But were it to begin would do the ſame.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: There are two Seas in Corinth, and two Queens,
And but there, not two ſuch in the ſpacious Univerſe;
I came to tender you the man you have made,
And like a thankfull ſtreame to retribute
All you my Ocean have enrich'd me with.
You told me once you'ld marry me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Another mock? you were wont to play faireplay,
You ſcorne poore helps; he that is ſure to win,
May ſlight mean harts, whoſe hand commands the Queen

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let me be held the Knave through all the Stock
When I doe ſlight my Miſtris; you know well
The gracious inclination of the Queene,
Who ſent me leave this morning to proceed
To marry, as I ſaw convenience,
And a great gift of Jewels: Three daies hence
The generall ſacrifice is done to Veſta,
And can you by then be accommodated
Your ſervant ſhall wait on you to the Temple.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Till now
I never felt a reall joy indeed.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Here then I ſeale my duty, here my love,
Till which vouchſafe to weare this Ring, deare Miſtris;
Twas the Queens Token, and ſhall celebrate
Our Nuptialls.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Honour ſtill raiſe, and preſerve
My honour'd Lord, as he preſerves all honour. Exit Euph.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Why ſhift you places thus Merione,
And will not lend a word? Could'ſt thou ſo ſoone
Leave ſorrow as the place, how bleſt were I,
But 'twill not be; griefe is an impudent gueſt,
A follower every where, a hanger on,
That words nor blowes can drive away.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Deare Siſter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Who can be ſad? out with theſe Tragick Lights,
